en.value: start the car
I'm trying to start the car but it's not starting. I think there's a problem.
drive
I like to drive but not when there's a lot of traffic.
motorway
You need to drive carefully on the motorway.
speed limit
The speed limit on motorways in Britain is 70mph.
traffic lights
You have to stop when the traffic lights are red.
park
Where can I park? There aren't any spaces.
petrol
We're going to stop for petrol.
passenger
Most cars can hold 4 passengers and a driver.
five-star hotel
We can't afford to stay at a five-star hotel. It's too expensive.
reception
Where's the reception?
book
Hello, I would like to book a room, please.
fully booked
There aren't any rooms left I'm afraid. The hotel is fully booked.
high season
The hotel is always very busy in high season.
low season
Prices are usually cheaper in low season.
half board
Our hotel is half board so we get breakfast and dinner included in the price.
full-board
All meals are included at full-board hotels.
check in
When you arrive at the hotel you need to check in at the reception.
check out
Before you leave the hotel, you must remember to check out.
it's fine
Jim said it's fine if we meet at 3 o'clock.
go ahead
Go ahead, you can eat as much cake as you want. It's your birthday!
sounds good
That sounds good. Let's leave at 5 o'clock.
I approve
I approve of your decision to move to Japan.
no problem
No problem, Shaun. Come over when you're ready.
good idea
Good idea. We'll pick you up in half an hour.
I have no objection
I have no objection to you going on holiday with your friends.
Let's go away for the weekend!
Describing a short holiday and expressing opinions
Going by car
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
When you are ready to begin the test, you can [k]start the car[/k].
OK, I'm ready!
OK, I would like you to [k]drive[/k] to the end of the road please.
Which way should I go at the end of the road?
Turn left at the [k]traffic lights[/k] and then go straight on.
Am I driving well? Do you think I'll pass?
I'm sorry but I can't tell you until the end of the test.
OK, I'm sure I will, I'm a great [k]driver[/k]!
Driving instructor
Wendy
Select the correct option.
Select the words in the correct order.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
At the hotel
Hello, I'd like to [k]book[/k] a room for July.
I'm sorry but we're [k]fully booked[/k] for July.
OK, what about August?
I'm afraid we haven't got any rooms for August either. It's [k]high season[/k].
When does [k]low season[/k] begin?
Low season generally starts in October.
OK, November would be good. Do you have a single room, [k]full board[/k], for one week starting on the 10th, please?
Yes, of course. Can I take your name please?
Thomas
Marta
When you travel, do you usually stay at a hotel or do you prefer another type of accommodation?
I always prefer to stay in a hotel. Last time I went on holiday we were camping, but it was raining for the entire time. I like to be able to use the mini bar and order room service.
Grammar: Present perfect continuous
The sentence focuses on the length or duration of the action.
I've been waiting here for ages.
True or false?
She's been painting her house all day.
She's finished her dinner.

The Present Perfect Continuous tense is used to talk about actions that started in the past and continue to the present, or repeated actions that have an effect in the present. We use the Present Perfect Continuous tense to focus on the length of time or repeated nature of the action.
I've been waiting here for ages. We've been coming to this restaurant for years.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Sentence
Present situation
She's been running in the park.
[k]Now she looks hot and tired.[/k]
[k]She has new shoes.[/k]
[k]She starts work at 5pm.[/k]
She's been playing football since she was 10 years old.
[k]And now she's very good at it.[/k]
[k]She looks tired now.[/k]
[k]She got up early today.[/k]
She's been standing at the bus stop for a long time.
[k]And now she's very bored![/k]
[k]She likes to take the bus.[/k]
[k]She's reading her book.[/k]

We use the Present Perfect Continuous tense to highlight how long the action continued for or that it happened a lot of times in the period leading up to the present. We use time phrases that lead up to the present time:
I've been waiting for ages He's been training since he was 10 They've been working all day
[k]I've[/k] [k]been[/k] [k]trying to contact you[/k] [k]all day.[/k]
[k]We've[/k] [k]been[/k] [k]playing[/k] [k]a lot of tennis[/k] [k]recently.[/k]
[k]She's[/k] [k]been[/k] [k]staying[/k] [k]in a hotel[/k] [k]this week.[/k]
To form positive sentences in the Present Perfect Continuous tense we use have + been + -ing form of verb. With personal pronoun subjects, 'have' is often contracted:

I have been waiting... = I've been waiting...
She has been working... = She's been working...
[k]Don't worry,[/k] [k]I haven't[/k] [k]been[/k] [k]waiting for very long.[/k]
[k]They[/k] [k]haven't[/k] [k]been[/k] [k]saving[/k] [k]enough money.[/k]
[k]Albert[/k] [k]hasn't[/k] [k]been[/k] [k]going out much.[/k]
To form negative sentences in the Present Perfect Continuous tense we use have + not + been + -ing form of verb. 'have + not' are often contracted:

I have not been working... = I haven't been working...
She has not been training... = She hasn't been training...
[k]You look tired,[/k] [k]what[/k] [k]have[/k] [k]you[/k] [k]been[/k] [k]doing?[/k]
[k]Have[/k] [k]you[/k] [k]been[/k] [k]going to the gym[/k] [k]a lot?[/k]
[k]Where[/k] [k]has[/k] [k]he[/k] [k]been[/k] [k]staying?[/k]
To form questions in the Present Perfect Continuous tense we put the subject between 'have' and 'been'
Have you been working all day?
He's been [k]standing[/k] in the rain for ages. Let him in!
stand
[k]We've[/k] been driving all day. We need a rest.
We're
We haven't been spending much time together [k]recently[/k].
last year
What have [k]you[/k] been doing all day?
he
Carlos has [k]been[/k] working all day.
gone
Present Perfect Continuous tense - I look forward
[k]I've been looking forward|I have been looking forward[/k] to my holiday for ages.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
Present Perfect Continuous tense - we not work
[k]We haven't been working|We have not been working[/k] very hard today.
Present Perfect Continuous tense - you stand
[k]Have you been standing[/k] there very long?
Present Perfect Continuous tense - you do
What [k]have you been doing[/k] today?
Present Perfect Continuous tense - I try
[k]I've been trying|I have been trying[/k] to finish this assignment for hours.
